item.title: TarragÃ³, 8b+ max., 240m in a day âœ… FFA [ğŸ‡«ğŸ‡· in the comments]This route is unique. 5 pitches : 6b, 8b,
item.description: TarragÃ³, 8b+ max., 240m in a day âœ… FFA [ğŸ‡«ğŸ‡· in the comments]This route is unique. 5 pitches : 6b, 8b, 8a, 8b+, 7c+/8a. The rock isnâ€™t exactly perfect though : dusty, fragile conglomerate, holds breaking every other tryâ€¦ But the climbing is super athletic and sustained, on a massive overhang, surrounded by the magical landscape of Montserrat (Catalunya). I thought Iâ€™d be able to send it pretty quickly. No crazy hard moves, and the style seemed to fit me well. But it turned out to be way harder than expected! After working each pitch separately, on my first ground-up go, I fell at the very top of pitch 4 (8b+). The following days, I couldnâ€™t even get past the first crux of the 8b+, after fighting my way through pitch 2 (8b), which I only sometimes sent on my second try. Last October 15th, after a day of rain, the rock was still slightly humid. I sent P1-3, then made it through the first crux of P4, getting close to the spot where Iâ€™d fallen on day oneâ€¦ Suddenly, I was hanging in the rope again, a hold broke in my hand. The situation felt hopeless. Failing because of something beyond my control was even more frustrating than falling from my own mistake. I felt the fatigue overwhelming me and the doubt setting in. I knew that I had maybe missed my chance to make it.I took a breath, found a new beta, rested, and went for one final try. This time, in a full-on fight, shaking on each holds, everything finally came together. I clipped the anchor. I topped out the final pitch in thick fog, completely drained but deeply happy. What a journey!Many thanks to @jimzimmermann_massagemedical , my partner, who was extremely close to sending it, but the conditions during the last two days we had left were the worst of the trip : fog wrapped the cliff in humidity all day long. Weâ€™ll be back!I climbed all the pitches in lead. Route opened by David TarragÃ³, first freed by the @hermanospou in 2013, and later repeated by @edumarin1 , @sebertheclimber & @jorge.diazrullo. Thanks to all of them for the inspiration!ğŸ“¸ @melanie_nacnac @mammut @scarpa_de @alouette_cycles @baechlibergsport @morandconstructionsmetalliques @tcssectionjurassienne @scarpa_world

item.title: Youâ€™d think a frozen couloir would be the last place to feel calm. But for Franziska SchÃ¶nbÃ¤chler, i
item.description: Youâ€™d think a frozen couloir would be the last place to feel calm. But for Franziska SchÃ¶nbÃ¤chler, itâ€™s the only place that makes sense. No noise. No pressure. Just the sound of her ice tools, the cold in her lungs, and the quiet reminder that sheâ€™s doing this for no one but herself. Sheâ€™s still in the competition world - where every move is judged, every result matters, and the pressure to deliver never really lets up. Even at her best, she wondered: Was I climbing for me, or for everyone else?Head to our YT channel to watch the full episode.
